item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Top Websites to Buy Lacrosse Gear 1. LacrosseMonkey-Why? Because they offer the best combination of pricing, latest gear and gear packages. 2. South Swell Lacrosse-Why? They have an excellent starter package, fantastic customer service and outstanding pricing on the latest gear. 3. Lacrosse.com-Why? Great deals, lots of great gear and they ship very quickly. 4. ComLax-Why? They have a nice starter package and offer the latest gear at great prices. 5. LaxWorld-Why? They are huge into lacrosse supplying some of the best college teams in the country and offer a great selection of gear. If youre looking for ratings of gear go to LaxShopper as they have many customer reviews and ratings of all lacrosse gear. If youre looking to shop locally there are a couple of options. 1. Breakaway Sports in Bellevue located at 10830 NE 2nd Pl (425) 451-3299 2. Sports Authority in either Issaquah or Bellevue 3. Play It Again Sports in Seattle, Renton and Lynnwood usually have a decent selection of used and new gear. My preferences for helmets are as follows: 1. Cascade CPX-R 2. Cascade CPX 3. Cascade CPV 4. Cascade CLH2 All helmets should be cardinal red with silver visor and chin.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Mount Si Lacrosse Club has been approved by the Tanner Jeans Memorial Foundation (TJMF) Athletic Fund as an eligible organization to participate in their scholarship program. The TJMF provides an athletic scholarship fund to help financially challenged families pay for up to 50% of the registration costs and approved fees associated for approved youth athletic programs in the Snoqualmie Valley. All families/kids that are enrolled in the Snoqualmie Valley School District and meet the financial requirements are eligible to apply for a scholarship for participation in the MSLAX club. This includes all program levels from Youth to High School. The fund is managed through Si View Parks District. All applications must be filled out per the guidelines and submitted to SVPD for review. These are reviewed per the guidelines established between TJMF and Si View. The Si View team will make a decision on the applicants scholarship request based on the information provided. All applicant information is kept confidential. To learn more about this organization please go to TannerJeans.com

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Mount Si Lacrosse Club was formed in 2010. The Boys High School program is a member of the Evergreen Conference of High School Boys Division 2, which also includes Redmond, Sammamish, Liberty, and Lake Washington. Home games are played on the football field at Snoqualmie Middle School, located at 9200 Railroad Ave SE, Snoqualmie, WA 98065 at the intersection of Railroad Ave SE & Meadowbrook Way SE. View Snoqualmie Middle School in a larger map About High School Lacrosse in Washington State Lacrosse is the fastest growing sport in the U.S. and in Washington State the sport has seen double-digit growth in six of the last eight years. In 2010, over 2,700 high school students representing 83 boys (www.WHSBLA.org) and 55 girls (www.WSLAX.org) varsity and jv teams in eastern and western Washington compete in a nine-week season March May. The annual Boys and Girls Washington State High School Championships take place in late May. For daily high school lacrosse results or to receive results through an RSS feed, please visit http://www.uslax-wa.org/media.html Boys Youth Lacrosse The Boys Youth program for grades 2nd through 8th is a member of GELL (Greater Eastside Lacrosse League) and plays home games at Si

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: As we move ahead with girls youth lacrosse here is some information about how the divisions work with the youth girls. Washington Schoolgirls Lacrosse Association Youth League is currently comprised of the following Divisions: U15 Gold This division is designed to be the most elite level of play currently being offered in the league. Teams consist of 7th and 8th grade players. U15 Silver This Division is designed for the emerging programs of 7th and 8th graders. 6th graders are allowed to play with this level if there is no program for them to appropriately play at the U13 level. 5th graders may practice with their U15B teams but are not allowed to play in games. U13 This Division is designed for teams comprised of 5th and 6th graders. U11 This Division is designed for a modified game of 7 v 7 for 3rd and 4th graders U9 This Division is the entry level of the sport and is designed for 2nd grade players. Currently, there is no select or travel Division of play. Eligibility: Players who live in the Snoqualmie School District boundary must play for the Mount Si Lacrosse girls youth teams. What You Need to Play Girls

item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: Junior division for 5th/6th grade This is a competitive division with 4-5 events per week. Players must manage multiple sports. Missed practices will result in loss of playing time. Players are expected to be at all games. Senior division for 7th/8th grade This is a competitive division with 4-5 events per week. Multiple sports are not encouraged as a greater time commitment is required. Missed practices will result in loss of playing time. Players are expected to be at all games.

item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: The 2nd-4th grade teams play a modified 7 on 7 game to maximize playing time. It is largely instructional and this modified version helps these young players to learn to play the game effectively. Commitment is 1-2 practices per week and weekend games. What do you need to play at this level? Girls lacrosse stick Goggles Mouth guard Players purchase their own gear. What does it cost to play? The cost for the spring season is $145 Click here to Register for the upcoming season.

If the gate happens to be open it could be closed and locked at any time and you would be unable to get out. Mandatory Equipment: Players are responsible for bringing the following equipment to practice and games. Please put your name on all gear. Mouth Guard. item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: If you want to improve your game and your conditioning you need to do the following: 1. Play Wall Ball and Work on your shot. Try this routine. This routine could also be completed with a partner or group. Passing, catching and shooting efficiently and accurately make you a better player. To be a varsity level player you must be able to throw, catch and shoot with both hands! 2. Running. Interval training is best for lacrosse as the changing of speeds and the stopping to rest simulates game situations. An example of an interval workout would be to sprint the width of the lacrosse field touch the line and sprint back (15-20 seconds) then jog back and forth for 45 seconds to 1 minute. Repeat this 10-15 times x 4-5 days a week. The goal would be to build up to 25-30 of these intervals. Distance running will also improve your conditioning level. Theres no need to run more than 5 miles. 2-3 miles is more than enough at a time. 3. Get in the weight room. We have a specific program for lacrosse which builds strength without adding a lot of bulk. If you would like a copy

item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: THE WALL DRILL Your lacrosse stick should become part of your body! These drills must be performed in the correct manner. If your form is sloppy, such as letting the stick hang down off the shoulder, you will be slinging the ball and thus wasting your time. CORRECT FORM MUST BE ADHERED TO, OR YOUR EFFORTS WILL BE WASTED. To become proficient in passing and shooting, the player must be able to propel the ball from the stick with the wrist snap. Many beginning players pass and shoot with an arm motion, or push the ball, which causes the ball to leave the stick on a low trajectory resulting in a low pass or shot. An excellent way to develop the wrist snap is to utilize the wall. Go to a cinderblock or brick wall and stand approximately 3 to 5 yards away. Any wall will work (no windows), but a smooth concrete surface at least 10 feet tall is the best. You can and will observe daily improvement if proper technique is maintained. Increase the reps as wrists become stronger. Aim for as many reps as possible with desired form, however. This is a lefty-righty work out. Attempt to

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Mount Si Lacrosse Club was formed in 2010. The Club is a recognized tax exempt charitable organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The Boys High School program is a member of the Evergreen Conference of High School Boys Division 2, which also includes Redmond, Union, Liberty, and Overlake. The youth program was also formed in 2010 and played their first year under the Snoqualmie Valley Youth Lacrosse name. The youth program was also part of Issaquah Youth Lacrosse in its inaugural year.

What is Lacrosse and how can I find out more about it?

Go to US Lacrosse.org where you will find rules and basic information.

What equipment do we need and where can we get it?

Click here to get to our Gear Page.

What do I have to do to Register?

Registration FAQ Page

What programs do you offer?

Boys and Girls from 2nd Grade through 8th Grade Boys High School

What is your refund policy should my child register and decide not to play?

Please refer to the policies information under the Resources tab.

How much practice time is involved to play for MSLC?

Usually two practices per week and one game per weekend for the Youth teams. High School practices four-five times per week plus weekday and Saturday games.

Can my child play up a level?

No, lacrosse rules mandate that each player plays at their own grade level.

Can a new player be competitive?

New players at all levels can become highly competitive through dedication and hard work. Many skills come quickly to players who've played sports like football, soccer, hockey and basketball.

Can you play lacrosse in inclement weather?

Yes, lacrosse in all weather sport! Two exceptions are lightning in the area and excess snow on the field.

Can parents volunteer to coach and help out with teams?

Yes! We are a volunteer organization and need all kinds of help to make the program strong. All teams need timekeepers, scorekeepers, and team parents. If you have coaching experience, please let us know.

Who do I contact if I want to ask a question or volunteer?

Send email to admin@mountsilacrosse.org

Mouth Guard (2 recommended so you always have one) Goggles Girls Lacrosse Stick Cleats Water Bottle Optional BUT highly recommended equipment: Light-weight gore-tex jacket Sweatshirt or microfleece Glovesanything that will keep hands warm and dry Stocking cap Hand warmer packs A bag to keep your gear in What does it cost to play? item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Drop off your item at the Rally between 10-11 am on Sunday, November 18, which will be held at Mt Si High School in the commons area. What kind of equipment will we accept in the swap? Sticks of any size or style Gloves without holes Shoulder, elbow, chest pads (no rips or tears) Heads that are not bent, cracked, or broken Unused mesh Practice goals, lax walls, any kind of backyard practice items Please NO HELMETS! For safety reasons, we cannot accept used helmets for the equipment swap. SELL it, TRADE IT, or GIVE IT AWAY When you arrive, you will tag your item.If you are selling something, you will fill out an envelope for each item with your name and mailing address on it. Bring change to buy a stamp for each item youre selling (50 cents each) so that we can mail your payment to you. You may also pick it up at 3 pm if you cant wait for the mail. All items left over at the end of the rally can be taken home at the end of the day orwill go into storage until the next swap event.

item.title: High School Boys
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: About High School Lacrosse in Washington State Lacrosse is the fastest growing sport in the U.S. and in Washington State the sport has seen double-digit growth in six of the last eight years. In 2010, over 2,700 high school students representing 83 boys (www.WHSBLA.org) and 55 girls (www.WSLAX.org) varsity and jv teams in eastern and western Washington compete in a nine-week season March May. The annual Boys and Girls Washington State High School Championships take place in late May. For daily high school lacrosse results or to receive results through an RSS feed, please visit http://www.uslax-wa.org/media.html High School Boys Program This is a Varsity level program for boys in 9th grade through 12th grade. The program is dedicated to a high level of competition, sportsmanship and honoring the game of lacrosse. We currently compete in Division II of the WHSBLA and the KingCo Conference. Our Conference opponents are Liberty, Garfield, Redmond, Ballard and Roosevelt. We will have a tryout period the first 3 days of practice after which players will be placed on Varsity, JV or C Team. We will have a JV or C team as long as we have enough players. To field teams below the varsity level our program must have at least 35 players. At that time we can field a JV or a Freshman team. 2012 Season Information First Day of Practice: February 25, 2013 Location: Mount Si High School Stadium Time: 8:30pm

Here's your chance to play lacrosse under the lights! Mount Si Lacrosse Club will be offeringtwo 2013Fall Lacrosse clinics in November! These will provide current lacrosse players the opportunity to get their stick out and work on their skills as well as introduce new kids to the game. Youth and High School coaches from the Mount Si Lacrosse Club will be running the clinic. WHO:The clinic is for boys and girls from 2nd grade through 8th grade. WHEN:The sessions will be November 10, 2013 from 3pm - 5pm and November 17, 2013 from 5:30pm to 7:00pm. WHERE:On the turf and under the lights at Mount Si High School HOW MUCH:The clinic is FREE, but please register so we know you're coming! WHAT TO BRING:It is a "sticks only" clinic, so no special gear is needed. Don't have a stick? Don't worry!! Mount Si Lacrosse has sticks to use for those who do not have their own.

CLICKHERETO REGISTER!

item.title: Boys Lightning (Grades 2-4)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
2013 Season Info:

  • We have 49 players this season; 14 on the Practice squad and 35 on the Game squad.
  • With 35 players we will field two teams that will participate in games on Saturdays.
  • These teams will be equally balanced across all skill levels and will not be separated into an A and B team.
  • This is consistent with GELL guidelines and a practice shared by all league teams.
  • Keeping things simple, we will have a Red team and White team.
Seeding for the teams will be based on assessments carried out during the first 2 weeks of practice. Final assignment will be communicated prior to our first game, which will be played on March 16th. More information will be provided on this topic closer to the first week of practice.
  • HOME games will be played at Snoqualmie Elementary School
  • AWAY games will involve travel to familiar locations like Issaquah, Kirkland and Mercer Island.

Key Dates

Sat, February 23at 3:00pm - first practice Weekday Practices (Wednesday and Friday Snoqualmie Elementary)
  • 5-6:30 before Daylight Savings Time (Feb 27th, Mar 1st, 6th, 8th)
  • 6-7:30 after DST (March 13th onward)
Games
  • First Game is Sat, March 16th
  • Schedule and Times are TBD
  • Click to check the GELL website for game schedules
Buddy System/Mentor With a lot of new players this year, we will use a buddy/mentor system that will link returning players with new players.
  • Returning players will be matched with new players in pairs or triples.
  • Players will be mixed across ages and schools to ensure cross group relationships.
This system will help us transition from drop-off to the start of practice; with players finding their buddies, help their partner(s) get ready and start warming up before practice starts. Coaches/Team Manager/Practice Assistants (more TBD) Brian Spence 206.261-4594 cell brian.spence@outlook.com Jennifer Spence-Team Manager jenniferlspence@hotmail.com Wade Schafer Carlos Chandler Kristin Pastoriza Steve Beinner Matt Field The Lightning Division operates with active parent participation. Parents are encouraged to help coach each Lightning team. No experience with Lacrosse is necessary.This is not a competitive league; with the exception of the traveling team, this is recreational and for developmental play. The commitment level for Lightning is generally 1-2 events per week and players are encouraged to try multiple sports at this level. There is also a Lightning Development team that is for advanced players at this level. See below for details. Each of these divisions can have multiple teams and competition levels. MSLC Lightning Development Team What is the Lightning Development Team? This program is an opportunity for experienced 3rd and 4th graders to play at a higher level of competition than is possible in our traditional Lightning sessions. The team will play full field Lacrosse (on a field that is 110 by 60 yards with 10 players per side) against other competitive programs in our area. There will be eight to ten games. Q: What is required? Your player will need to make a greater time commitment than is required with the standard Lightning program. Your player is expected to attend the standard Friday Lightning session in addition to at least one other weekly practice and a game on Saturday. As part of this commitment, we are requesting lacrosse to be your players primary athletic activity during the spring season. Q: Who is eligible? 3rd and 4th graders registered in the IYL Lightning program with at least 1 or more years of experience playing lacrosse. Q: How will the team be formed? MSLC will be fielding one Lightning Development Team for the 2011 season. For those players who are ready and can make the time commitment, we want to provide every opportunity to play and we have a maximum roster size of 20 players per team. Q: How do I register for the team? The registration period will open beginning December 1, 2010 and run through February 15, 2011. Returning 4th graders (who played MSLC in the spring of 2010) will have preference during this period. Registration will be accessible via the online MSLC online registration system. Q: Are there additional registration fees associated with the Development team? Yes, in addition to the standard Lightning program fee, there will be an additional MSLC registration fee of $75. This fee will go toward incremental field reservation costs, referee fees and additional equipment and uniform costs. Additionally, for liability purposes, players are required to have an active US Lacrosse player membership which carries an additional $25 annual fee. You will be prompted to supply a valid US Lacrosse membership # during IYL registration. If your player doesnt have a current membership, the MSLC registration system will direct you to the appropriate US Lacrosse registration site. Q: How much playing time will my player get? Everyone plays in MSLC. We have a dual mission at MSLC that can be best summarized as "Participation and Preparation". Please visit the MSLC Boys Program FAQ for details. Q: What about sportsmanship? These players will be representing the MSLC program and our community and we expect the highest level of sportsmanship and good behavior. This is also the expectation of all parents. Please read A Parents Role in Lacrosse then review the US Lacrosse "Parents Guide" to learn more about how best to support your players success in the "fastest game on two feet"! Q: What is the goal of the team? Our focus is on building skills throughout the season, working together as a team and having fun while at the same time providing additional full field competition not provided by the Friday Lightning session. We want the kids to finish the season energized and excited to play Lacrosse another season while helping to prepare the advancing 4th graders for the 5/6 Junior program. Q: Who is coaching this team? Dennis Simmons will be the head coach assisted by other experienced youth coaches. Q: My son is interested and committed, what do I do next? Complete the online registration for the 3/4 Development Team on the MSLC website following the registration instruction provided above. We will send out a communication to registered team members once the registration process is complete.

item.title: Youth Boys
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The youth boys program is divided in to three levels: Lightning: This level is for 2nd through 4th grade boys and operates in two formats. The first is for beginning players, Lightning (Practice Only) usually 2nd and 3rd graders, and is a two day a week instructional clinic that progresses into full field play by the end of the season. The second is Lightning (Practice and Games), a competitive team that plays full field games in a competitive league. This is for more experienced players, usually 3rd and 4th graders, and is not recommended for first time players. Junior: This level is for 5th and 6th grade boys. Practice is usually two to three days a week and league games are on Saturdays. This level also has playoffs. Senior: This level is for 7th and 8th grade boys. Practices are 4 to 5 days a week with most games on Saturday and a select few during the week. This is a highly competitive level.

item.title: Girls
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Mount Si Lacrosse Club will field girls teams in the 2nd-4th grade, 5th-6th and 7th-8th grade age groups.

  The 2nd-4th grade teams play a modified 7 on 7 game to maximize playing time. It is largely instructional and this modified version helps these young players to learn to play the game effectively. Commitment is 1-2 practices per week and weekend games. The 5th-6th and 7th-8th teams play with 12 players on each side and on a full field. We believe in full participation so everyone gets to play. This is not a select team. Players should be ready to commit to several practices during the week and weekend games. GIRLS FAQ What are the rules in girls lacrosse? Click here for the girls rules. Will there be a high school girls team? We are unable to offer girls high school team at this time as we just don't have enough players. Teams will depend on interest level. Teams are required to have a minimum of 16 players to be able to field a team. 18-22 players is the ideal number for a girls lacrosse team at these levels. As we build our youth girls program a high school program will become more likely. Is the girls game just like the boys game? No, girls lacrosse is its own unique game. It has the speed of the boys game but does not have the contact of the boys game. The game is played with the same ball but the stick and gear that is required is different. Girls do not have helmets (except the goalie), protective gloves or shoulder pads. Girls have their own specialized gloves and wear goggles to protect their eyes. The girls have 12 players on a side rather than the 10 that the boys have. For a complete description of the girls game from US Lacrosse click here. Check out this great video about girls lacrosse! Click here to REGISTER No experience is required!

Sign up for the Mount Si Girls Lacrosse mailing list

Here is some information about how the divisions work with the youth girls. Washington Schoolgirls Lacrosse Association Youth League is currently comprised of the following Divisions: U15 Gold This division is designed to be the most elite level of play currently being offered in the league. Teams consist of 7th and 8th grade players. U15 Silver This Division is designed for the emerging programs of 7th and 8th graders. 6th graders are allowed to play with this level if there is no program for them to appropriately play at the U13 level. 5th graders may practice with their U15B teams but are not allowed to play in games. U13 This Division is designed for teams comprised of 5th and 6th graders. U11 This Division is designed for a modified game of 7 v 7 for 3rd and 4th graders Currently, there is no "select" or "travel" Division of play. Eligibility: Players who live in the Snoqualmie School District boundary must play for the Mount Si Lacrosse girls youth teams. What You Need to Play Girls Lacrosse 1. goggles-several styles to choose from 2. stick-players choice, so many options. If you want a recommendation just email us. 3. mouth guard 4. gloves-optional Starter packages can be found on the links from our website on the side tabs or the companies listed on the gear page located on the high school tab. Coaching Opportunities: If you are interested in coaching please let us know. We can provide training if you've never coached lacrosse before. The girls youth association also has training for new coaches. If you have prior coaching experience in any sport that is a plus but is not a requirement.

item.title: Registration FAQ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Please read this page VERY carefully. There is a lot of information here!

Q: How do I register?

All registration is managed online. Our registration program is secure and all online payments are deposited directly into the Mount Si Lacrosse Club merchant account. Important! Do not wait to register! Teams will fill up fast and we need you to register so that we can plan for rosters, schedules, fields and coaches.
  • Early Bird Registrationfor the regular season all levels will open on Sunday, November 3rd, 2013. Early bird discounts end at 11:59 pm on Sunday, November 10th, 2013.
  • Regular Registration continues from November 10th through 11:59 pm on Sunday, January 5, 2014.
  • Late Registration runs from January 6, 2014 to February 17, 2014. Late registration fees increase by $35.
Registration Steps: 1. Are you eligible? You must reside in the Snoqualmie Valley School District to play lacrosse for Mount Si Lacrosse Club. 2. Renew or join US Lacrosse. All players must have a current membership in US Lacrosse to complete registration and be placed on a team. All memberships must be valid. USL membership helps control insurance costs and provides important coverage for our organization. Important! You must complete this step before proceeding through on-line registration! Have your membership number and expiration date at hand - registration cannot be completed without it. Already have a USL number? You can check your membership status by going to the USL Membership Information Page. Need a new USL membership, or to renew? You can renew or join USL by going to the USL New Membership Page. Please be sure to check that you are registering under Mount Si Lacrosse Club and not under one of the other local programs. USL membership and expiration dates are verified with USL for all player rosters after registration closes so it is important that your membership is associated with Mount Si. 3. Register online here: http://mtsilacrosse.bonzidev.com/home.php 4. Get equipment. All Junior, Senior, and High School Division players provide their own gear. Lightning Division can rent gear on a first come, first served basis. See the Gear page for recommendations and resources. Please use the links on our website, we earn money for the club when you click from the Mount Si Lacrosse website to these vendors. 5. Bookmark the Mount Si Lacrosse Club Website. Check in often for updated information as well as watch for email announcements. The Mount Si Lacrosse Club website is our primary means of communication with our members. Q: What is the cost? Registration fees for the 2014 spring seasons are: Boys
Lightning-Practice Only (2nd-4th Grade Beginners) $100 early bird/$115 regular
Lightning-Games (3rd-4th Grade Advanced) - $185 early bird/$200 regular
Juniors (5th/6th Grade) $300 early bird/$315 regular
Seniors (7th/8th Grade) - $300 early bird/$315 regular
High School $385 early bird/$400 regular
Girls
U9 (2nd Grade) $60 early bird/$75 regular
U11 (3rd/4th Grade) $170 early bird/$185 regular
U13 (5th/6th Grade) $185 early bird/$200 regular
U15 (7th/8th Grade) $185 early bird/$200 regular
ONE WEEK ONLY!
  • Early Bird Registration for the regular season all levels will open on Sunday, November 3rd, 2013. Early bird discounts end at 11:59 pm on Sunday, November 10th, 2013. Early registrants will receive $15 off the regular price.
  • Regular Registration continues from November 10th through 11:59 pm on Sunday, January 12th, 2014.
  • Late Registration runs from January 13, 2014 to February 16, 2014. The Late registration fee is $35.
Scholarship information can be obtained by email to admin@mountsilacrosse.org. Fully paid registration is required before a player will be placed on a team. Need-based scholarships are available for qualified families - please contact see the Financial Aid page for more information. Q: What is included in the registration fee? Fees are budgeted to cover organization/team expenses with no additional fund-raising required to meet the programs operational expenses. MSLC is and independent non-profit Washington State Corporation, an IRS recognized 501(c)(3) and not a WIAA Interscholastic sports program. We do not receive funding from the school district or any other entity. The Club operates entirely by registration fees and fundraising. Players are responsible for their own equipment. The club furnishes game uniforms at all levels. In addition, registration fees pays for the operation of the club which include, but are not limited to, field rentals, league fees, some tournament fees, referee fees, practice equipment, insurance, registration transaction costs. High School players are responsible to purchase a practice jersey offered for $45 through the club. Parents will be assessed for the full replacement cost of Club uniforms and equipment that are not returned. Game equipment is not provided nor included in the registration fee. Rental equipment is only available for Lightning players and a security deposit is required for all rental equipment packages Q: Can I break down the fees into payments? Payment plans are available at the time of registration by choosing the "Payment Plan" option during the registration process. Q: Why do I have to sign a concussion form? Concussions are serious injuries, and we take them seriously. Moreover, the state's laws about concussion awareness and prevention require that you sign the forms annually. The jurisdictions in which we play enforce the law, and require the forms. So in addition to the "click through" in registration, youll also have to sign and turn in the hard copy form before your player can participate in any practices or games.
  • DOWNLOAD THE CONCUSSION FORM HERE
Q: What is the refund policy? Anyone registering and choosing not to participate before the start of practices may request a refund less a 10% processing fee. Anyone opting to quit after practices have started but before the first game may request a refund less a 25% processing fee. No refunds after the start of games. Any refunds will not be processed until all MSLC equipment has been returned to the MSLC. This policy also applies to injuries. If a player is removed from an Mount Si Lacrosse Club program due to falsified information given during the registration process which affects the player's eligibility, an additional $100 administrative charge will be deducted after the refund is calculated as outlined in this section. Q: Do returning players have priority? Anyone who played on an Mount Si Lacrosse Club team during the prior regular season will have priority registration status until January 7th and will be placed on the new season's teams first. If returning players miss the January 7th priority placement deadline they will be registered on a first-in/first-on basis. Mount Si Lacrosse Club does not reserve slots for returning players past the January 7th date; if you register late and we do not have space for you a full refund will be issued. Q: Is everyone who registers assigned to a team? We strive to accommodate every player who registers but Mount Si Lacrosse Club is experiencing explosive growth and we are limited by the number of coaches and fields. Player applications that are wait-listed are not guaranteed a roster spot. Wait-listed players are subject to a first-in/first-on policy. The best way to guarantee a spot is to register early! Q: What happens if a player is on a wait list? Any player that is on the wait list must still register and pay the fee. If no team is formed for a wait-listed player, MSLC will refund the registration fee. Q: How many players are on each team? Approximately 24 players in the Junior and Senior Divisions; approximately 24 for the Lightning Division. High School has a maximum of 75 (teams can be formed for Fr/Soph, JV and Varsity). Multiple Teams at each level may be established dependent on fields and coaches that are available. Q: How are the teams organized? Lightning Division teams are organized by grouping players according to their home Elementary School Area to the greatest extent possible with some balancing to ensure optimal team size. Junior and Senior Division teams are grouped by ability. Coaching staff, grade levels and player experience are also factored in and there will always be some balancing to ensure optimal team size. Q: Who are the coaches? We have some of the best coaches in the state, and we're still committed to making them better and bringing in other experienced, quality coaches. We require that all our coaches at each level become certified US Lacrosse Coaches. US Lacrosse provides expert training for coaches at all levels each year. Many of our coaches are already certified with US Lacrosse and continue to build their skill and knowledge as coaches. The sport has grown in our state and our community so fast that it has quickly soaked up the adult coaches who played in high school or college - the traditional source for coaches in most youth sports programs. We're actively developing new coaches and recruiting experienced coaches for the more advanced players.

item.title: Financial Aid
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Mount Si Lacrosse is committed to finding a way for every child who wants to play lacrosse to participate. We have received generous assistance from donors who have designated their funds to be used only to help with player fees. To apply for financial aid, please download our scholarship award information & application.
  • All applications for financial aid are completely confidential.
  • You may apply for financial aid even if you have already registered for the season
We as a club know that there are other circumstances that may affect ability to pay, like an ill family member, loss of a job, single parent, or reduction in pay. We also take this into consideration when awarding scholarships. If these or any other circumstances affect your family, please explain in the "comments" section so we can do our best to help. Please do not hesitate contact us at registrar@mountsilacrosse.org if you have any questions!

item.title: Boys Juniors (Grades 5 and 6)
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: Junior division for 5th/6th grade This is a competitive division with 4-5 events per week. Players must manage multiple sports. Missed practices will result in loss of playing time. Players are expected to be at all games.

item.title: Girls U11 (Grades 3-4)
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
The 3rd-4th grade teams play a modified 7 on 7 game to maximize playing time. We believe in full participation so everyone gets to play. Teams will have one to two practices during the week and weekend games. This level is largely instructional and the modified game helps these young players learn to play lacrosse effectively. What do you need to play at this level?
  • Mouth Guard
  • Girls Lacrosse Stick
  • Goggles
  • Cleats
  • Water Bottle
Optional but recommended equipment:
  • A bag to keep your gear in
  • Light weight gore-tex jacket
  • Sweat shirt or micro-fleece
  • Glovesanything that will keep hands warm and dry
  • Stocking cap
  • Hand warmer packs
Players purchase their own gear. What does it cost to play? The cost for the spring season is $185 Click here to Register for the upcoming season.

item.title: Girls U13 (Grades 5-6)
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
The 5th-6th team plays with 12 players (11 field and 1 goalie) on each side and on a full field. We believe in full participation so everyone gets to play. There will be practices during the week and 9 games. Games are usually scheduled on Saturdays unless there is a field or team conflict. We are also planning on playing in 2 or 3 Washington Schoolgirls Lacrosse Association Jamborees.

The spring season kicks off in late February and runs through the first week of June. As teams are built and schedules are solidified we will communicate to all players and post the information below. Mandatory Equipment: Players are responsible for bringing the following equipment to practice and games. Please put your name on all gear.
  1. Mouth Guard. We recommend getting two so you always have an extra in your bag. Make sure to fit it properly so it is comfortable and does not cause gagging.
  2. Goggles
  3. Girls Lacrosse Stick
  4. Cleats
  5. Water Bottle
Optional BUT highly recommended equipment: Spring is cold & wet around here so dress for the weather!
  • Light weight gore-tex jacket
  • Sweat shirt or microfleece
  • Gloves. Anything that will keep hands warm and dry.
  • Stocking cap
  • Hand warmer packs
  • A bag to keep your gear in
What does it cost to play? The cost for the spring season is $200 Click here to Register for the upcoming season. If you're currently involved in winter sports, that should be enough running and jumping to prepare you for our first practice. If you're not involved in winter sports or you want to do a little extra, below are some suggestions. Remember to warm up and stretch before full speed exertion.
  1. Light jog (3-5 minutes)
  2. 40 yard sprints. 20 seconds rest between each sprint (5 minutes)
  3. Down and back sprints. 20 yards distance. Work on change of direction and acceleration back to start line.
  4. Wall Sits 1 minute each (set of 3)
  5. Planks 1 minute each (set of 3)
Also, go to You Tube and search by US Lacrosse training tips for ideas. 5 Fundamental Skills: Spend some time with friends, siblings or parents working on these skills.
  1. Grip on stick. Light hands. Top hand should hold stick in fingers, not palm.
  2. Cradling (motion of stick while ball is in your possession) work left and right hand on top.
  3. Ground Balls. Bend your knees, rear end down, stick low to ground, accelerate through the ball.
  4. Catching. Nice target. Arms slightly bent and away from your body. Head of stick should give as you catch ending up next to your ear.
  5. Throwing. Stick is a lever. Push with top hand, pull with the bottom. Motion is much like throwing a ball.
For throwing and catching, the best exercise is to play wall ball. Watch video below:

item.title: College Recruiting
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If you are looking to play post high school there are plenty of opportunities. Use the tools listed here to help you in your search. LacrosseRecruits.com is the official recruiting tool of US Lacrosse. There are fees involved but it is highly regarded as the best source for recruiting high school lacrosse players. Northwest Colleges with Lacrosse Programs The opportunities are there if you want to play lacrosse beyond high school. Washington Washington State Western Washington Central Washington Gonzaga Pacific Lutheran University of Puget Sound Simon Fraser Idaho Montana Oregon Oregon State Portland State Boise State Whitman University of Portland Western Oregon Southern Oregon Willamette University College of Idaho Don't see your college of choice here? Check out all the teams in NCAA Divsion 1, Divsion 2, Division 3, MCLA, NJCAA (Junior College Lacrosse).

item.title: Helmets
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: Our preference for helmets is as follows: 1. Cascade CPX-R or Pro 7 (high school boys) 2. Cascade CLH2 or CPX-R (Junior and Senior boys) 3. Cascade CS (Lightning Boys) Lightning should be white Junior should be white. Senior divisions can be white or scarlet red with silver visor and chin. High School boys must have scarlet red with silver visor and chin. Breakaway Sports in Bellevue carries a few of the high school/Senior helmets in stock. If you wish to order a red helmet please contact us. Cascade Lacrosse Helmet Sizing Chart Cascade CS (Youth) Size Head Size Standard 19 3/8" to 20 9/16" Cascade CLH2 Size Head Size XXX-Small Up to 20 1/2" XX-Small 20 1/2" to 21 3/16" X-Small 21 3/16" to 21 1/2" Small 21 1/2" to 22 3/16" Medium 22 3/16" to 22 1/2" Large 22 1/2" to 23 3/16" X-Large 23 3/16" to 23 1/2" Cascade CPV Size Head Size X-Small 20 15/16" to 21 7/8" Small/Medium 21 3/4" to 22 1/2" Medium/Large 22 3/8" to 23 1/8" Cascade CPX-R Size Head Size Standard 22 3/8" to 23 5/8" Cascade PRO7 Size Head Size Standard 22 3/8" to 23 5/8"

item.title: Where To Buy
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
Top Websites to Buy Lacrosse Gear

  1. Harrow has given MSLC a promo code to order online and get 20% OFF RETAIL.Use promo code: TinaTownsley20
  2. LacrosseMonkey offer the best combination of pricing, latest gear and gear packages.
  3. South Swell Lacrosse Offers an excellent starter package, fantastic customer service and outstanding pricing on the latest gear.
  4. Lacrosse.com Great deals, lots of great gear and they ship very quickly.
  5. ComLax They have a nice starter package and offer the latest gear at great prices.
  6. LaxWorld They are huge in lacrosse, supplying some of the best college teams in the country and offer a great selection of gear.

Local Stores for Lacrosse Gear

If you're looking to shop locally there are a couple of options. 1.Breakaway Lacrosse is located at 1048 116th Ave. NE - Ste. 180 Bellevue, WA 98004-4698 (425-451-3299) 2. Dick's Sporting Goods on the Issaquah Highlands has a great selection of lacrosse gear. (425-427-9284) 3. Sports Authority in either Issaquah or Bellevue- They carry all the gear and lacrosse shoes. They have a girls starter package and women's lacrosse shoes.(425-961-2020) 4. Play It Again Sports in Woodinville,Seattle, Renton and Lynnwood usually have a decent selection of gently used and new gear. 5. Superior Seconds in Issaquah has a variety of gently used and new lacrosse gear and seasonal rental packages.

item.title: Girls Gear
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
What you need to play girls lacrosse:

  • Mouth Guard (2 recommended so you always have one)
  • Goggles
  • Girls Lacrosse Stick
  • Cleats
  • Gloves Optional and not to be confused with boys gloves
  • Goalies wear specialized gear including a helmet, goalie stick, chest and throat protector
Girls Gear Packages can be purchased from the following online sites: South Swell has a great package at around $90. ComLax has 3 different starter packages all around $100. Locally you can get gear packages from: 1.Breakaway Lacrosseis located at 1048 116th Ave. NE - Ste. 180 Bellevue, WA 98004-4698 (425-451-3299) 2. Dick's Sporting Goodson the Issaquah Highlands has a great selection of lacrosse gear. (425-427-9284) 3.Sports Authorityin eitherIssaquahorBellevue- They carry all the gear and lacrosse shoes. They have a girls starter package and women's lacrosse shoes.(425-961-2020) 4.Play It Again SportsinWoodinville,Seattle,RentonandLynnwoodusually have a decent selection of gently used and new gear. 5. Superior Secondsin Issaquah has a variety of gently used and new lacrosse gear and seasonal rental packages. Other great sites to buy girls lacrosse gear: Longstreth has an excellent selection and great prices.

item.title: Shafts and Heads
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
Shafts

The shaft you choose will generally depend on the position you play and the level that you play. Youth players do not need an expensive shaft.High School players need a stronger shaft. Shafts can be made of different metals, wood and composite materials.

Attack Shafts

Attack shafts are for players who are midfielders and attack. These shafts are 30".

Defense Shafts

These long poles are 60" and are used by defensemen.

Goalie Shafts

They look like a hybrid of an attack and defense shaft and begin at 40 inches but can be cut down.

Heads

Heads depend on what level of play and not necessarily on position of the player. Be sure to check which heads are high school legal. Some are legal for all levels (usually labeled an "X" head) and some are legal for college lacrosse only. High school legal heads are also legal for youth play. Heads can be purchased pre-strung or unstrung. Coaches recommend hard mesh for the heads. Custom stringing can be done via online (several of the online retailers offer this service) or it can be done locally at Breakaway Lacrosse which is located in Bellevue (425-451-3299) or Dicks Sporting Goods located in the Issaquah Highlands (425-427-9284). There are several Senior and High School lacrosse players that will string as well...ask around! You can also ask your coach for player names and numbers. Not sure what or how to buy? Click here for some recommendations.

item.title: Gloves, Shoulder Pads and Arm Guards
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
Gloves

Gloves vary greatly in quality. You need quality gloves. You will get hit in the hands and you need to protect your hands. [caption id="attachment_433" align="alignright" width="240" caption="Warrior Electrik"][/caption] All of our players should be wearing red gloves. At the high school level it is required that all players have the same color gloves. .::Glove Sizing Chart::.
Gloves Height
Small 10in. 4'6" & under
Medium 12in. 4'6" - 5'6"
Large 13in. 5'6" + Over

Shoulder Pads

Protection for your upper body and your arms is very important. Make sure that your pads fit properly. The color of your shoulder pads is not important. Pads that are too big or too small could cause you to be injured. Find a place where you can try on gear before you buy. Height is a general guide to pad size but because body types vary so greatly it is best to try gear on first. Because you need to try shoulder pads on there is no size chart posted here. [caption id="attachment_437" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Warrior MPG Hitman 8.0"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_438" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Brine King Jr."][/caption]

Arm Pads/Guards

Arm pads/guards are universal until you get to high school. In high school the type of pads you use will change depending on position. Ask your coach for recommendations. Defensemen and Attack will usually wear completely different arm protection. .::Arm Protective Sizing Chart::.
Arm Guard Age Weight Height
Small 5-9 years old 90 lbs. & under 4'6" & under
Medium 9-13 years old 90 lbs.-140 lbs. 4'6" - 5'6"
Large 13+ years old 140 lbs. + 5'10" + Over

[caption id="attachment_439" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Warrior Nation Flex Elbow Guard"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_440" align="alignright" width="166" caption="Warrior MPG 10 Elbow Pad"][/caption]

item.title: Goalie Gear
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: What you need for goalie gear: Goalie Gloves: special gloves with more padding. Goalie stick and head Goalie chest protector Throat protector-these come in a tie on version and a permanent one that attaches to the helmet. Goalie pants are optional but are a nice luxury for younger goalies. A protective cup is mandatory for goalies. Gear can be purchased from any of the retailers listed on the Where to Buy tab.

item.title: Product Reviews
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
Lacrosse Gear Ratings and Reviews

If you're looking for ratings of gear go to LaxShopper as they have many customer reviews and ratings of all lacrosse gear. Sports Stop has a great gear guide that you can view online or you can order the guide by mail. Easton, best known for its baseball gear is now making lacrosse shafts and heads. They seems like another solid entry in the lacrosse world. They've already convinced pros Casey Powell, Brett Queener and Michael Evans to endorse and use their products. I really liked the wood grain look to their shafts. If the shafts are as good as their bats then we can expect great things from Easton. The have a first in the lacrosse world-a fully adjustable head. Might not be ideal for more advanced players but for youth players it looks like a winner. They will also be introducing their new helmets very soon but I didn't get to see them at the Expo. There are two additional sites that review gear. They are: Lacrosse Equipment Reviews Lacrosse Gear Review

item.title: The Other Guys Tournament
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: We will be playing at Walter E. Hall Park at 1226 S.W. Casino Road in Everett. Walter Hall is conveniently located off of Hwy 526, the Boeing Freeway. You can access a map here. The tournament schedule will be as follows: Saturday, June 11 9:30 a.m. (1) Everett vs. (2) Ballard 10:30 a.m. (3) Mount Si vs. (4) Liberty 12 noon (3) Mount Si vs. (1) Everett 1 p.m. (2) Ballard vs. (4) Liberty 2:30 p.m. (1) Everett vs. (4) Liberty 3:30 p.m. (2) Ballard vs. (3) Mount Si Sunday, June 12 9:30 a.m. Seed 2 vs. Seed 3 10:30 a.m. Seed 1 vs. Seed 4 11:30 a.m. All-Star Game (two 15-minute halves with five minute halftime) 12:30 a.m. Consolation 1:30 p.m. Championship All regular season rules apply with the following additions. These were outlined on the registration form, but are listed here as a reminder.... Play is open to all players from 2011 roster. If ejected from a game, player or coach must sit out teams next game. NO EXCEPTIONS. Twenty-minute running halves with 5-minute half. Clock does not stop on time-outs. No time outs can be called during last 5 minutes of each half. TIE GAMES on Sunday. If at the end of regulation the game is tied, a 3v3 Braveheart will be conducted. Each team will field two middies (attack, defense) and a goalie. First to score wins the game. In the event of a penalty, the offending player must go to the midfield wingline opposite the bench side. Play will begin with ball in the stick of offended teams player at the corner of the box near the bench side. Each team is guaranteed five games. Teams will play a round robin on Saturday for seeding on Sunday. In case of a tie, goals AGAINST will be used for determination; team with fewest Goals Against moves on. Each team is required to have a Parent Volunteer. That Parent Volunteer shall keep time and score at each team game and report team scores to Tournament Director at the end of each game. Where NFHS and above stated rules are not addressed, Field Director has final say.

item.title: Off-Season Conditioning
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: If you want to improve your game and your conditioning you need to do the following: 1. Play Wall Ball and Work on your shot. Try this routine. This routine could also be completed with a partner or group. Passing, catching and shooting efficiently and accurately make you a better player. To be a varsity level player you must be able to throw, catch and shoot with both hands!Other stickwork like cradling can be done in your back yard, while sprinting or on a distance run. Make sure you work on your off-hand cradling as much or more than you do with your dominant hand. Get a Cradlebaby so you can cradle indoors without breaking stuff in your home. 2. Running. Interval training is best for lacrosse as the changing of speeds and the stopping to rest simulates game situations. An example of an interval workout would be to sprint the width of the lacrosse field touch the line and sprint back (15-20 seconds) then jog back and forth for 45 seconds to 1 minute. Repeat this 10-15 times x 4-5 days a week. The goal would be to build up to 25-30 of these intervals. Another route is to run 40 yard sprints. We run sets of 10 with 10 seconds rest in between each sprint. The goals is to run 4 sets. You get 90 seconds of rest and 50-60 seconds of sprint. We also run 300s. This is a longer sprint with intervals of 25 yards. You run 12 consecutive 25 yards sprints (up 25 and back 25). Goal is 45 seconds, the max time it should take is 60 seconds. Distance running will also improve your conditioning level. There's no need to run more than 5 miles. Between 2-5 miles is more than enough at a time. This should be done at least 3 times a week with a maximum of 5 times per week. 3. Get in the weight room. We have a specific program for lacrosse which builds strength without adding a lot of bulk. You can download weeks 1-8 here. For weeks 9-16 click here.

item.title: Drills
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: THE WALL DRILL "Your lacrosse stick should become part of your body!" These drills must be performed in the correct manner. If your form is sloppy, such as letting the stick hang down off the shoulder, you will be slinging the ball and thus wasting your time. CORRECT FORM MUST BE ADHERED TO, OR YOUR EFFORTS WILL BE WASTED. To become proficient in passing and shooting, the player must be able to propel the ball from the stick with the wrist "snap." Many beginning players pass and shoot with an arm motion, or "push" the ball, which causes the ball to leave the stick on a low trajectory resulting in a low pass or shot. An excellent way to develop the wrist snap is to utilize the wall. Go to a cinderblock or brick wall and stand approximately 3 to 5 yards away. Any wall will work (no windows), but a smooth concrete surface at least 10 feet tall is the best. You can and will observe daily improvement if proper technique is maintained. Increase the reps as wrists become stronger. Aim for as many reps as possible with desired form, however. This is a lefty-righty work out. Attempt to do as many reps as possible. Remember, your goal is to strengthen the wrists, to become proficient in releasing the ball with the snap of the wrists, to gain hand speed, and to develop a quick release. Do as much as much of this routine 4-5 times a week for 15-20 minutes (no more). Beginning players should start at 30 reps with each hand before moving to a different part of the drill. Your goal should be to get through the entire drill (50 reps with each hand) with each hand in under 20 minutes. If you only get through part of the drill, it is easy to set a goal for next time. Proper 1 hand technique: Wearing gloves, hold the stick in one hand at its balance point and then place the head of the stick in the "box" area next to the ear. Then with one hand, "snap" the wrist which will cause the ball to come out of the stick in a straight line and bounce off the wall straight back into the stick kept in the box area. This will be difficult at first. Do not take shortcuts. Keep the head of the stick in the box and not down off the shoulder. Proper 2 hand technique: Wearing gloves, hold the stick with your top hand approximately half way down the shaft of the stick. Your opposite hand should cover the end cap. Snap the top wrist while bringing the bottom hand towards your dominant arm pit. This will help to keep your stick in a vertical postion. Try to keep the head of the stick in the box at all times. Passing is like casting a fishing line. Be ready for the ball to return in a hurry. Change your foot stance as you change your hands, that is lead with your left foot if passing from the right, and so forth. Stick protection is important. Proper Cross hand technique: This is the similar to two hand technique. Hold the stick such that the dominant hand is across your body. The head of the stick should be kept in the "box" near the opposite ear. This will be awkward at first but only the advanced players will get to this stage. DRILLS: (Beginners 30 reps with each hand) 1. 1 hand: catch and 1cradle 2. 2 hands: catch and 1 cradle 3. 2 hands: quick stick 4. 2 hands: split drill -catch righty, switch and throw lefty/ catch lefty switch and throw righty 5. 2 hands: catch, face dodge, and throw 6. 2 hands: catch, fake, and throw You must be at 50 reps with each hand before passing this point. 1. 2 hands: cross handed 2. 2 hands: behind the back 3. 2 hands: running along the wall throwing and catching. 4. Be creative: if you get to this stage, you have earned the right to! Remember the above must be performed in the correct manner, that is: stick in the box, overhand motion, wrist snap. If your form is sloppy, such as letting the stick hang down off the shoulder, you will be slinging the ball and thus wasting your time. CORRECT FORM MUST BE ADHERED TO, OR YOUR EFFORTS WILL BE WASTED.

item.title: Policies 2014
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
Mount Si Lacrosse Club Policies 2013_2014   Update to the Tournament Team Policy Due to feedback and requests for clarification from the Mount Si Lacrosse Club parent community, the MSLC Board has reviewed, clarified, and approved the following Tournament Team Policy to provide consistency across all levels of our program. Tournament Team Policy
  • The MSLC Tournament Teams will be selected based on regular season player performance and skills assessment.
  • Tournament Team Players - MSLC Coaches will select 19-20 Tournament Team Players
  • Alternate Tournament Team Players - Coaches will also select 5-6 Alternates who can practice and will have a chance to fill in for scheduling conflicts or injury of Tournament Team Players
    • Coaches will stack rank Alternates by performance and skills assessment.
    • Coaches will ask Alternates in order of rank to play in a tournament for a Tournament Team Player who has conflict.
    • Alternate Players will be invited to all-Tournament Team practices providing a great opportunity for continued development of their game.
    • Alternate players have a choice if they would like to participate.
    • There will be no fee charged directly to Alternate players from MSLC but these players will still need to registered as an "Alternate - Practice Only" tournament team player through MSLC registration process.
  • Tournament Team Players who are selected and accept the invitation to play areresponsible for all tournament fees, regardless of whether they will play in all or some of the games.
  • Once selected for the team, Tournament Team Players must be transparent and let coaches know of any scheduling conflicts ASAP due to other sports commitments, school activity conflicts, family commitments, vacations plans, or personal/religious (Sunday) conflicts. Alternate players may also be asked to participate in tournament games due to Tournament Team Player injury at the discretion of coach.
  • Missed Tournament Team practices from Tournament Team Players or Alternates will result in reduced playing time during tournament games and will be determined by coaches.
  • Tournament Team Players are responsible for collecting reimbursement from the Alternate player's family, facilitated by the coach.
  • Reimbursement will be a flat fee based on the average cost of all the tournaments.
    • For example, if the full tournament fee is $160 for four tournaments, then each tournament fee is $40.
    • In this situation, the parents of the Tournament Team Player may also chose not to recoup or Alternates may get "sponsored" as a result.
      • If the families of a Tournament Team Player is unwilling to pay the full price for all tournaments, they can choose not to participate.
Alternate Players can also choose to not participate if they are not willing to pay Tournament Team Player upon their request for reimbursement.

item.title: Girls U9 (2nd Grade)
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded: The 2nd grade introduction to lacrosse program consists of 6 weekly one-hour practices starting in April and games at the end-of-year Washington Schoolgirls Lacrosse Jamboree in early June. The 2nd grade teams play a modified 4-on-4 game and concentrate on learning the basics of girls lacrosse. This is a great way to get your 2nd grader introduced to lacrosse! The cost for this spring program is $75. Click here to Register for the spring program.

item.title: Girls U15 (Grades 7-8)
item.dc:creator: coach
item.content:encoded:
The 7th-8th team plays with 12 players (11 field and 1 goalie) on each side and on a full field. We believe in full participation so everyone gets to play. There will be practices during the week and 10 games. Games are usually scheduled on Saturdays unless there is a field or team conflict. We are also planning on playing in 2 or 3 Washington Schoolgirls Lacrosse Association Jamborees. The spring season kicks off in late February and runs through the first week of June. As teams are built and schedules are solidified we will communicate to all players and post the information below. Mandatory Equipment: Players are responsible for bringing the following equipment to practice and games. Please put your name on all gear.
  • Mouth Guard (2 recommended so you always have one)
  • Goggles
  • Girls Lacrosse Stick
  • Cleats
  • Water Bottle
Optional BUT highly recommended equipment:
  • Light-weight gore-tex jacket
  • Sweatshirt or microfleece
  • Glovesanything that will keep hands warm and dry
  • Stocking cap
  • Hand warmer packs
  • A bag to keep your gear in
What does it cost to play? The cost for the spring season is $290 Click here to Register for the upcoming season.

item.title: First Tournament - Cavalier Invitational
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The newly formed Mount Si Lacrosse Club ventured up to Bellingham last weekend for their first tournament, the North County Cavalier Invitational. Teams from across Washington met at Whatcom Community College's Orca Field on Saturday and Sunday. Team captain Matt Mahrer scored the first goal of the season within the first 30 seconds of the game against North County, then followed up with a second goal a few minutes later. Highlights included strong face off play by freshman Beau Bachand and vicious defensive play by Tom Evans and Nathan Whited through all three games. Scores: North County (11-2) Wenatchee Valley (12-0) Stanwood (8-0) Mount Si Lacrosse Club plays their first league games against Sammammish on Tuesday, March 16 and Lake Washington on Thursday, March 18.

The Mount Si Nike Gear site is finally ready to go! Go to www.brandteamstore.com The passcode is 1CMSILX (it is case sensitive) Important things to know:
  • Most of the items are Men's items
  • Women's only items are the Road Trip jacket and pants as well as the Women's Commander jackets (be careful because there is a men's commander jacket as well. The women's is labeled as "women's"
  • The shipping address listed at the end of the ordering process is not for shipping. It is just to calculate local taxes. Your orders will not go to Mt. Si high school.

You must order your gear before March 31st. Our gear will arrive 10 days after the end of the sales period.

item.title: 2012 Mount Si Midsummer Mayhem Tournament Wrap Up!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, July 7th, 2012, Mount Si Lacrosse Club hosted high school teams from Issaquah, Three Rivers, and the Crease Hoppers (representing Watcom and Skagit Counties) at its inaugural lacrosse tournament. With Mount Si as a backdrop and the amazing sunny weather, it was a fantastic day for lacrosse! In addition to the games, the tournament hosted a skills competition where each team selected one player for an accuracy competition, and another player for a hardest shot competition. The accuracy competition took three rounds before Mario Midilly of Three Rivers beat Mount Si's Zach Gappa. For the hardest shot competition, Markus Fakima of the Crease Hopper's fired an impressive 99 mph shot to win (followed by another shot at 98 mph) to win! Special thanks to Tina Townsley of Harrow Sports for providing the fantastic prizes for the winners!

[gallery]

Of course, an event like this could not be held without the support of volunteers. Thanks to everyone who helped! A special Wildcat thanks goes out to Kristi and Rick Woods, Leah Harrison, Laura Maher, Gary Kinner, Tom Crandall, and Steve Burns...and everyone who helped with the concessions stand!

Finally, aspecial thanks to the following sponsors for their generous support!

- - Gold Sponsors - -

  • Sahara Pizza - Thanks for providing the pizzas!
  • Cascade Mountain Tech
  • Bradson Consulting
  • Woodman Lodge
  • RC Painting
  • DirtFishRally School
  • North Bend Bar & Grill
  • Harrow Sports

- - Silver Sponsors - -

  • Compass Outdoor Adventures
  • Sno Thai Restaurant
  • La Fogata Mexican Restaurant
It was a great day of lacrosse and Mount Si Lacrosse Club looks forward to hosting the 2013 Mount Si Midssummer Mayhem Tournament next year! Hope to see you there!

item.title: Warrior Dash
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
What is the Warrior Dash? Warrior Dash is an extreme 5K race that has racers climbing over several obstacles, crawling through mud and jumping through fire. Warrior Dash is an all day running event, where participants and spectators enjoy a festival area complete with beer, live music and turkey legs. If you haven't volunteered or participated in the Warrior Dash before, it's an important fundraising event that keeps our players from having to do more difficult fundraisers like car washes and bake sales. in past years, some players have earned as much as $180 toward their season fees. Check out theWarrior Dash website What should I wear? DON'T wear nice shoes or nice clothes. Depending on the job you are assigned to do, you may get muddy or need to stand in mud. You might even get a hug from a muddy person. What do we get during our volunteer shift?
  • Free breakfast, lunch and snacks
  • T-Shirt
  • Community Service Approval
  • VIP Parking Pass
  • Access to live music and festival
What is expected from our volunteers? Volunteers will devote full-time attention and energy to Warrior Dash and during the agreed time slot, will not engage in any other activity. Warrior Dash is an extreme event bringing about an intense work environment. Your organizations duties, along with the Red Frog Events staffs, involve maintaining a safe atmosphere for all participants, spectators, etc. Duties may include working event registration, answering participant questions, managing parking, overseeing obstacles, serving beer, selling tickets, etc. The event will go on rain or shine and by signing the agreement, your group will be expected to be in attendance. By volunteering, each person from the organization understands and acknowledges Warrior Dash is an extreme event and accepts all risks associated with the event.

Tables of 8 people are available for purchase for $344.00. Reserved tables will receive preferential seating reservations. The cost of your ticket includes your dinner and beverages for the evening. (Yes, that means an open bar....Nice!)

Our very own Mount Si High School Jazz players will be entertaining us for the reception and silent auction.
Want to join our auction team or have an item to donate? Please email Kristi Wood:KristiWood1@gmail.com
The evening is hosted by special guest Larry Snyder of Benefit Auction Associates, known for his fun and entertaining style and ability to create an environment of generous giving.
Keep up with the Auction highlights & all of ourMSLC happenings on Facebook!We'll be posting updates and featuring the fun items that will be auctioned off. Questions? Kristi Wood can be reached at kristiwood1@gmail.com or 425-256-1701.

item.title: Midsummer Mayhem Tournament
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Mount Si Lacrosse Club will be hosting its third annual Mount Si Midsummer Mayhem high school lacrosse tournament on Saturday, July 12th,2014. The tournament is held at Mount Si High School at 8651 Meadowbrook Way SE in the beautiful Snoqualmie Valley. Additional tournament details:
  • Each team plays 3 games.
  • Games are 22 minute running halves with a 5 minute half.
  • Games will run on the hour starting at 9:00 a.m.
  • Tie games resolved with via 3v3 Braveheart.
  • There is a skills competition for hardest shot and accuracy, and new this year, a new 5-player team relay event! Each team will select champions to come forward to represent their team in this fun event!
  • All players and coaches will receive a t-shirt.
  • Concession stand will have drinks and food available. Restaurants are also conveniently located nearby.
  • Fee per team is $450.
  • Teams must provide proof of valid US Lacrosse membership per player and have copies of signed player concussion forms.
  • Teams must provide proof of valid US Lacrosse membership per player and have copies of signed player concussion forms
  • Teams need to provide a parent volunteer to help at the scoring table for each game.
For registration details or other questions, please contact the tournament organizer, Raymond Yan, atraymond.yan@digipen.eduor 425-753-7532.

item.title: Mount Si Lacrosse Club is very pleased to announce Mr. Chris Castleberry as the new Varsity Head Coach
item.dc:creator: kim
item.content:encoded:
Along with this announcement please mark your calendars as there is an all high school meeting on October 17th at 2:30PM at the Freshman Campus Library. All players can meet Coach Castleberry at this time and learn more about his coaching philosophy and his expectations for the coming year.
Attendance is expected for all new and returning players. For players in football or with other conflicts, you will have an opportunity during the Registration Rally November 10th to meet with Coach Castleberry.
Please read on to learn more about Coach Castleberry:
My lacrosse career began in Port Angeles, where I helped start the program, win a D2 State Championship with an undefeated season, and propel our program to the D1 level of play. While at Port Angeles I excelled as a goalie by both being named team captain and earning individual honors as team defensive most valuable player, and playing on the State All-star team.
During my senior year I answered the call to duty and joined the United States Marine Corps immediately following the terrorist attacks on September 11th. While in the Marine Corps I continued to play lacrosse, both at home, and abroad while deployed overseas. After playing in a joint service All-star team throughout Asia, I started the Marine Corps' first ever Varsity lacrosse team. I played the role of captain / coach and entered our team in competitive post collegiate mens leagues and tournaments, such as the Hawaii lacrosse invitational, and the jam by the sea tournament in San Diego.
While playing defense for my Marine Corps Lacrosse team I was scouted by the University of San Diego (USD), where I would continue my playing career from 2010-2012. I switched back to goalie and led the nation in saves and won MVP honors in post season tournament play against that years national champion contenders. After my first year playing for USD I was the only new player to be named as team captain, and was also voted to the student board of directors.
Due to injuries sustained while in the Marine Corps, I had to end my collegiate playing career early, but would continue my involvement in the sport as a coach.
I started my coaching career in 2004 as head coach of the Rancho Bernardo Middle School team in San Diego. After a successful first season coaching middle school, I was asked to move up to the high school level, where I would be named the head lacrosse coach of a Varsity program at the age of 22, which was the youngest age for any head varsity lacrosse coach in San Diego.
I coached at Mount Carmel High School for three seasons, where I prided myself on my offseason involvement with the program. Our team participated in numerous summer, fall, and winter leagues, as well as conditioning and team building camps which I started. Off season development is something I strongly suggest for a successful program, which is why I coached at several camps and clinics, and led my team, and Starz elite teams to offseason tournament honors.
My most recent coaching experience was during my senior year this past spring, where I volunteered my time as the assistant coach and defensive coordinator for Helix Charter HS. I helped lead a developing urban program to its first post season appearance, with a team that had more first time players than returning players.
Lacrosse continues to be a major part of my life, and is so much more than just a sport to me. As a Snoqualmie Tribal Member, I take pride in being able to have played, and continue to coach "The Creators Game". I learned early on in my coaching career by an influential mentor, Dennis Yeatman, how coaching lacrosse is more than X's and O's; it's about building lasting relationships, teaching respect for the game, our opponents, and to everyone that has helped endure our game over the centuries. I am grateful to be afforded the opportunity to coach for Mount Si, and feel that I have been given the coaching opportunity of a lifetime. For such a young program, Mount Si is head and shoulders above any other 5th year program. By providing our young athletes the opportunity to play the game, it will surely prove beneficial in creating a winning and lasting program, a program that I am truly thankful and excited to be a part of.
Thank you for entrusting the future of Mount Si Lacrosse upon me, and I promise to lead the team with integrity and respect for my athletes and the Creators Game alike.
Yours,
Coach Chris
